title: Malin Andersson says she tried to take her own life after her baby's death in moving post
text:

Malin Andersson has opened about the loss of her baby daughter, admitting that she tried to take her own life after she died.

The Love Island star, 26, said she had no family to support her as her mum had died shortly before she gave birth in a heartbreaking Instagram post.

She bravely shared her story to mark Baby Loss Awareness Week and World Mental Health Day, alongside a picture of her stomach that revealed the scar from her caesarean.

Malin wrote: "The death of a baby is not a rare event. It can happy to anyone.

"I share my story, not just for any reason, but to give strength to those who have gone through similar, to drive improvements in the bereavement care and support available for those affected and in remembrance for my little girl Consy and others.

(Image: Brett D. Cove / SplashNews.com)

(Image: Instagram)

"It is also World Mental Health Day (Suicide Prevention) - and I for one know that I felt so low I attempted to take my own life - from previous events and also losing my baby.

"Straight after losing my baby girl I had no family around me and no support apart from my closest friends, and @sandscharity reaching out to me.

"Hospitals did not reach out to me apart from to discuss the post mortem and to register her birth and death at the same time.

(Image: Instagram)

"Not everyone has somebody there for them - It all links together, and the only way that we can create change and more awareness is to spread the word."

Malin finished her post by calling on her followers to remember all babies that have died during Baby Loss Awareness Week.

She added: "We remember the babies born sleeping, those we carried but never held, those we held but could not take home, those who came home but could not stay."

(Image: WENN.com)

Malin’s daughter Consy, who was born at 33 weeks, died from a severe heart condition in January when she was just four weeks old.

She was still grieving the loss of her mum, also named Consy, who had died from cancer in November 2017.

If you are struggling and need to talk, the Samaritans operate a free phoneline open 24/7 on 116 123, or you can email them at jo@samaritans.org
description: Malin, 26, posted a picture that revealed the scar from her caesarean as she bravely opened up about her grief
